raw_text:
Yukos seeks court action on sale
 
 Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset.
 
 Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear.
 
 Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal - which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on Sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer. Many observers believe that the unit, which produces 60% of Yukos' oil output, could ultimately fall into the hands of Surgutneftegas or even Gazprom, the state gas firm which opted out of the auction.
 
 The Russian government forced the sale of Yukos' most lucrative asset as part of its action to enforce a $27bn back tax bill it says the company owes. Yukos' US lawyers claim the auction was illegal because the firm had filed for bankruptcy and therefore its assets were now under the protection of US bankruptcy law which has worldwide jurisdiction. On Wednesday, Yukos will also seek further legal remedies to prevent the break-up of the group. "We believe the auction was illegal and we intend to pursue all legal recourses available to us," Yukos spokesman Mike Lake told Agence France Press. "If it exports that oil, it will be marketing a stolen product," he added. The future ownership of Yuganksneftegas remains unclear amid widespread suggestions that Baikal was established as a front for other interests.
 
 Speaking on Tuesday, President Putin said Baikal was owned by individual investors who planned to build relationships with other Russian energy firms interested in the development of Yuganskneftegas. President Putin also suggested that China's National Petroleum Corporation could play a role in the unit's future after signing a commercial agreement with Gazprom to work on joint energy projects. Yukos has claimed that the sale of its main asset will lead to the collapse of the company. Commentators and Yukos itself claim the firm is the target of a government campaign to destroy it because of the political ambitions of its founder, Mikhail Khodorkovsky.
llama3.2:1b: Yukos will seek court action in the US on Wednesday to challenge the sale of Yuganskneftegas by Baikal Finance Group. The company has filed for bankruptcy and Yukos is claiming that the auction was illegal due to lack of jurisdiction under US bankruptcy law. Yukos also seeks further legal remedies to prevent the breakup of its group.
llama3.2:3b: Yukos seeks sanctions against Baikal Finance Group for buying its main asset Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Russian government forced sale as part of back tax bill enforcement. Yukos' US lawyers claim auction was illegal due to bankruptcy protection. President Putin suggests individual investors and China's National Petroleum Corporation may be involved.
gemma2:2b: Yukos is seeking sanctions against Baikal Finance Group for the illegal sale of its main asset, Yuganskneftegas.  The Russian government forced the sale and Yukos claims the auction was illegal due to bankruptcy protection under US law.  Baikal's background and potential motives are unclear, but links to Surgutneftegas and Gazprom raise concerns about ownership and future control of Yuganskneftegas.  Yukos believes the sale will lead to the company's collapse, while President Putin suggests other interests are involved in the deal.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Yukos seeks court action over Baikal Finance Group's sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn. Russian media claim Baikal bought unit at state auction with strong ties to Surgutneftegas and Gazprom. Yukos will sue Baikal, but whether it can succeed remains unclear.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Yukos seeks court action against Baikal Finance Group for $20bn in damages over oil asset sale that Russia's main tax court has ruled illegal and will seek further remedies.
qwen2.5:3b: Yukos seeks court action against Baikal Finance Group for $20bn over the sale of Yuganskneftegas, which accounts for 60% of Yukos' oil output and was sold at a state-orchestrated auction. Yukos claims the sale was illegal due to its bankruptcy filing and accuses Baikal of having links with Surgutneftegaz or Gazprom. The company also fears break-up and possible theft if the unit is exported for use. Putin stated that Baikal's ownership includes individual investors planning relationships with other Russian energy firms, and suggested China’s National Petroleum Corporation could be involved in future projects. Critics believe Yukos faces a government campaign aimed at its founder Mikhail Khodorkovsky's political ambitions.

Baikal's background and its primary purpose of buying the unit are still unclear. deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Yukos seeking court action against Baikal Finance Group. Let me read through the provided text carefully.

First, I see that Yukos is suing the company for $20 billion in damages. They're going to the US court on Wednesday. The main reason they're appealing is because the Russian government ignored a court order last week that blocked the sale of Yuganskneftegas. I'm not exactly sure what Yogos' assets are, but it seems like Baikal's interest in it was being held by Surgutneftegas or Gazprom, which are other big oil companies.

I also notice mentions of Russian newspapers calling Baikal a competitor with links to Surgut and Gazprom. Observers think the unit could end up with those firms instead. There were claims about back tax bill owed by the company, which I guess is related to their current sale.

Yukos' lawyers are arguing that the auction wasn't lawful because they filed for bankruptcy. This would affect US bankruptcy law jurisdiction, meaning Yukos' assets might be protected differently. They're also seeking more legal remedies and suggesting political reasons behind their actions, like Mikhail Khodorkovsky's motives. The future ownership of Yuganskneftegas is unclear, with suggestions that Baikal could be a move to destroy the company.

So, putting it all together, Yukos is suing for financial damages, appealing an illegal sale due to Russian interference and potential changes in their assets. They're pushing through legal steps because they think they can't continue doing business without them, which is backed by political reasons.
</think>

Yukos seeks court action against Baikal Finance Group over $20 billion in damages for selling Yuganskneftegas, appealing an illegal sale blocked by the Russian government. The lawsuit aims to freeze Baikal's assets as their current owners might fall into other firms like Surgutneftegas or Gazprom. Lawsuits from Yukos' lawyers suggest they're seeking legal remedies and political motivations, with doubts about their future ownership of Yuganskneftegas.
tinyllama:1.1b: A Ukrainian court has ruled in favor of returning assets to Yukos, the Russian oil giant that filed for bankruptcy and is seeking damages from a private firm in the United States. The ruling allows the US firm, Yukos Oil Company USA, to sell off the company's assets worth $20 billion, including its stake in an energy project in Kazakhstan, known as Utyzhenie. While the Russian government has blocked the sale, Yukos is expected to challenge it further at a US court, where lawyers will also be seeking sanctions against Baikal Finance Group and its owner, Oleg Deripaska. The move comes amid wide speculation about the future ownership of Ukraine's largest oil producer, which has been plagued by corruption allegations and political ambitions that have threatened to destabilize the country.
tinydolphin:1.1b: This statement provides a brief overview of recent events involving Yukos, a Russian oil company, and Baikal Finance Group, a small company that bought the main asset of Yukos in an auction held by the Russian government. It suggests that Yukos was seeking legal recourse against Baikal for alleged violations of US bankruptcy law during the sale process. The statement also mentions potential ownership changes for the unit following the sale, with some suggesting it could be used as a front by investors interested in developing the Yuganskneftegas asset further.
phi:2.7b: The Russian oil giant Yukos is returning to court in the US to seek $20 billion in damages from Baikal Finance Group for buying its main asset at an auction that was illegal according to Yukos' lawyers. Yukos' future ownership of Yuganskneftegas remains unclear, with reports suggesting it could fall into the hands of Surgutneftegas or Gazprom. The Russian government forced the sale as part of a $27bn back tax bill and Yukos' US lawyers claim the auction was illegal because its assets were under bankruptcy protection. President Putin suggested that China's National Petroleum Corporation could play a role in Yuganskneftegas' future after signing an agreement with Gazprom.
orca-mini:3b: On Wednesday, Yukos will file court action seeking sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, which bought its main asset at an auction on Sunday. The company's US lawyers plan to request that Baikal assets be frozen in response to the Russian government ignoring a US court order to block the sale. Yukos claims that the auction was illegal and that the unit could eventually fall into the hands of Surgutneftegas or Gazprom, Russia's state gas firm which opted out of the auction. Yukos' main asset, Yuganskneftegas, produces 60% of its oil output and is crucial to its plans to develop the unit. The sale has been linked to the government's campaign to destroy Yukos, which President Putin said was owned by individual investors who plan to build relationships with other Russian energy firms interested in the development of Yuganskneftegas. Baikal's ownership remains unclear, but China's National Petroleum Corporation could play a role in the unit's future after signing a commercial agreement with Gazprom to work on joint energy projects.
hermes3:3b: Yukos seeks court sanctions against Baikal Finance Group for $20bn damages over sale of Yuganskneftegas asset. Yukos argues auction was illegal due to bankruptcy protection under US law.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Yukos returns to US court to sue Baikal Finance Group for $20bn damages, as Russian newspapers suggest Baikal has ties to Surgutneftegas and Gazprom. The Russian government forced the sale of Yukos' most lucrative asset due to a back tax bill, but Yukos claims the auction was illegal under US bankruptcy law. President Putin suggests China's National Petroleum Corporation could be involved in Yuganskneftegas' future, while Yukos argues the sale will lead to its collapse due to political ambitions by founder Mikhail Khodorkovsky.

Yukos plans to sue Baikal and others for $20 billion in damages and will attempt to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government ignored a US court order blocking the sale. Baikal's background remains unclear, but reports suggest links to Surgutneftegas, with speculation that the asset may ultimately go to Surgutneftegas or Gazprom. The Russian government forced the sale to recover a $27 billion tax bill, but Yukos argues the auction was illegal under US bankruptcy law. The company's US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after Russia ignored a US court order blocking the sale. Baikal Finance Group's background and motives for purchasing the unit remain unclear, with many observers believing it could end up in the hands of Surgutneftegas or Gazprom. President Putin suggested that China's National Petroleum Corporation could play a role in the unit's future development after signing an agreement with Gazprom on joint energy projects. Yukos argues that the sale of its main asset will lead to the collapse of the company, and it is likely the target of a government campaign due to the political ambitions of its founder, Mikhail Khodorkovsky.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Yukos plans to challenge Baikal Finance Group's $9.4 billion acquisition of Yuganskneftegas in US courts on Wednesday, seeking sanctions and damages for the allegedly illegal sale due to Yukos' bankruptcy protection. The Russian government forced this transaction as part of a $27 billion back tax claim against Yukos. Critics argue that Baikal may be linked to Surgutneftegas or Gazprom, suggesting the company's future ownership remains uncertain. President Putin claims Baikal is owned by individual investors planning to collaborate with Russian energy firms for Yuganskneftegas development and potentially China's National Petroleum Corporation. reference: Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset.Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages.Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale.Yukos' US lawyers claim the auction was illegal because the firm had filed for bankruptcy and therefore its assets were now under the protection of US bankruptcy law which has worldwide jurisdiction.Yukos has claimed that the sale of its main asset will lead to the collapse of the company.Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal - which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on Sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.Many observers believe that the unit, which produces 60% of Yukos' oil output, could ultimately fall into the hands of Surgutneftegas or even Gazprom, the state gas firm which opted out of the auction.
